title: Facial recognition bill knocked back
text:
People in shopping malls, airports and other public spaces could be subject to the laws, and when a criminal suspect is apprehended, they face being directly photographed by police and instantly identified.

Chair of the influential committee, Liberal Andrew Hastie said required safeguards were not adequately set out in the draft legislation.

The call for a rewrite is the first since national security laws put forward by the Howard government in the wake of the September 11, 2001 terror attacks.

"In the committee's view, robust safeguards and appropriate oversight mechanisms should be explained clearly in the legislation," Mr Hastie told Parliament.

"The committee also expresses broad support for the objectives of the bill but agrees that the bill, as it stands, does not adequately incorporate enough detail."

Mr Hastie said the regime should be built around privacy, transparency and subject to robust safeguards, while being subject to parliamentary oversight and "reasonable proportionate and transparent functionality".

The committee called for a participation agreement setting out the obligations of authorities using identity-matching services.

Separately, the committee said changes to passports law for identity-matching of data should not allow computerised decision-making. It called for redrafting by the government.

Advertisement

Shadow attorney-general Mark Dreyfus said Labor and Liberal members of the committee had united to call for a complete redrafting before the bill came back tot he committee.

"In taking this step, I congratulate all members of the committee for putting the national interest first and sending a strong message about the value of this committee," he said.

"If there is no intention for the proposed identity-matching services to be used to engage in mass surveillance activities, the government should no object to amending the bill to ensure that those services cannot, as a matter of law, be used in that manner."

The draft laws required a statutory review of the plan in five years.

The proposed laws for identity matching were agreed in a meeting of all Australian state and territory leaders with then-prime minister Malcolm Turnbull in October 2017.

The Coalition first introduced the legislation to Parliament in February 2018, but the bill lapsed at the May election.
description: An influential parliamentary committee has called for a rewrite of facial recognition laws, telling the Morrison government to add safeguards against abuse.
